description: Florida has cut more environmental protection jobs than any other state in the past 15 years, despite the challenges posed by increasingly intense hurricanes and sea level rise, according to a newly released national report.
title: Florida leads nation in cuts to environmental protection jobs, report says

description: Grief over the sudden death of a partner leads 1 in 6 surviving partners to experience such severe psychological distress that they begin taking sedatives or antidepressants. If the death also results in a noticeable loss of income, the share of widows and widowers using psychotropic medication is significantly higher. Economic insecurity greatly amplifies the mental strain after the death of a loved one, researchers conclude.
title: A partner's death can hit harder when finances are unstable

description: Gemini North captured new images of Comet 3I/ATLAS after it reemerged from behind the sun on its path out of the solar system. The data were collected during a Shadow the Scientists session—a unique outreach initiative that invites students around the world to join researchers as they observe the universe on the world's most advanced telescopes.
title: Comet 3I/ATLAS displays greenish hue in new Gemini North telescope images

description: Adults in Germany are better than the international average at coping with problems in new and complex situations. However, this adaptive problem-solving skill depends more heavily on sociodemographic characteristics than in other countries. This is shown by a new evaluation of the latest PIAAC study, in which adults in around 30 countries were tested.
title: German adults outperform international peers in complex problem-solving tasks, study finds

description: Viruses are typically described as tiny, perfectly geometric shells that pack genetic material with mathematical precision, but new research led by scientists at Penn State reveals a deliberate imbalance in their shape that helps them infect their hosts.
title: Unique bond identified as key to viral infection speed

description: A dissertation study at the University of Jyväskylä (Finland) developed two-dimensional fishnet-like structures from DNA origami for silicon surfaces and investigated how different conditions affect their formation. The results provide new possibilities for DNA-assisted lithography and thus for the fabrication of new types of materials, for example, for optics.
title: DNA origami lattices on silicon open new possibilities for large-scale nanofabrication

description: Canine induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells possess the ability to differentiate into any type of cell, making them a useful tool for investigating common canine diseases and disease states, including those of humans.
title: A new medium for canine stem cells that doesn't contain any human components

description: Much of the heavy rains that hit the Philippines during the Amihan northeast monsoon season between November and March are triggered by "shear lines": kilometers-long bands of converging warm and cold air that are constantly shifting and difficult to spot even via satellite.
title: Researchers track down elusive rain-triggering 'shear lines' in the Philippines

description: The microscopic organisms that fill our bodies, soils, oceans and atmosphere play essential roles in human health and the planet's ecosystems. Yet even with modern DNA sequencing, figuring out what these microbes are and how they are related to one another remains extremely difficult.
title: Smarter tools for peering into the microscopic world developed

description: The climate is changing and nowhere is it changing faster than at Earth's poles. Researchers at Penn State have painted a comprehensive picture of the chemical processes taking place in the Arctic and found that there are multiple, separate interactions impacting the atmosphere.
title: Feedback loops from oil fields accelerate Arctic warming and other atmospheric changes, study shows

description: The electrochemical CO2 (carbon dioxide) reduction reaction takes harmful pollutants and transforms them into valuable products like fuel. However, selectively tailoring various processes in this reaction to successfully and efficiently arrive at a particular desired outcome remains a challenge.
title: Rare-earth europium substitution allows for more control over CO₂-to-fuel conversion

description: In April 2025, the Main Marmara Fault below the Sea of Marmara in northwestern Türkiye experienced its largest earthquake in over 60 years. In a study published in Science, a team of researchers led by Prof. Dr. Patricia Martínez-Garzón from the GFZ Helmholtz Center for Geosciences in Potsdam, Germany, analyzes nearly two decades of seismic data framing the 2025 April magnitude M 6.2 earthquake.
title: Earthquake rupture along Main Marmara Fault shows eastward progression towards Istanbul

description: Researchers from the Institute of Genetics and Developmental Biology of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) have uncovered the long-elusive biosynthetic pathway of glycitein, a key soybean isoflavonoid. They also reveal how its production determines the plant's resistance to Phytophthora sojae.
title: Glycitein biosynthetic pathway sheds light on soybean disease resistance

description: The microscopic processes taking place in superconductors are difficult to observe directly. Researchers at the RPTU University of Kaiserslautern-Landau have therefore implemented a quantum simulation of the Josephson effect: They separated two Bose-Einstein condensates (BECs) by means of an extremely thin optical barrier.
title: Atomic Josephson contacts: How Bose-Einstein condensates replicate Shapiro steps

description: Aquatic plants are specialized evolutionary groups adapted to life in water. They play critical roles as food and medicinal supplies (e.g., lotus root and foxnut) and industrial raw materials (e.g., reeds), as well as in ecological restoration. While most aquatic lineages have independently evolved from terrestrial ancestors, the genomic dynamics underlying this adaptation remain largely unexplored.
title: Genomic study reveals how vascular plants adapt to aquatic environments

description: Droughts are lasting longer in Australia, particularly in some of our most populated regions, UNSW scientists have shown.
title: Droughts are lasting longer across Australia, study shows

description: Femtosecond laser-induced periodic surface structures can be used to control thermal conductivity in thin film solids, report researchers from Japan. Their innovative method, which leverages high-speed laser ablation, produces parallel nanoscale grooves with unprecedented throughput that is 1,000 times stronger than conventional approaches, strategically altering phonon scattering in the material.
title: Femtosecond lasers push the limits of nanostructures for thermal engineering

description: JCU Professor of Marine Biology Morgan Pratchett has published new research in Biology demonstrating the best injection method to kill the problematic Crown-of-thorns starfish and prevent them from spawning.
title: Injection method critical to controlling Crown-of-thorns starfish, finds study

description: Water is all around us, yet its surface layer—home to chemical reactions that shape life on Earth—is surprisingly hard to study. Experiments at SLAC's X-ray laser are bringing it into focus.
title: Water's enigmatic surface: X-ray snapshots reveal atoms and molecules at work

description: SpaceX and United Launch Alliance are combining for a busy week of rocket launches on the Space Coast.
title: SpaceX launches 1st of 5 missions on tap in next 8 days on Florida's Space Coast

description: Global human rights are in decline according to the findings of a recent study by researchers at the University of Rhode Island's Center for Nonviolence and Peace Studies.
title: Global Rights Project report spotlights continued troubling trends in worldwide inhumane treatment

description: Car manufacturers in Europe will have to include more recycled plastics in new vehicles under new EU rules agreed on by the bloc's countries and lawmakers on Friday.
title: EU agrees recycled plastic targets for cars

description: Black women are underrepresented in senior roles in British academia. As of May 2024, there were only 70 Black women professors.
title: Visible for diversity, invisible in research: The burdens Black female academics face in universities

description: People typically think about evolution as a linear process where, within a species, the classic adage of "survival of the fittest" is constantly at play. New DNA mutations arise and get passed from parents to offspring. If any genetic changes prove to be beneficial, they might give those young a survival edge.
title: Songbirds swap colorful plumage genes across species lines among their evolutionary neighbors

description: Holidays bring celebration, rest and, for many families, long stretches of indoor time. For some, this means tabletop games quickly reappear on kitchen tables. Games provide opportunities for learning mathematics actively.
title: Jigsaw puzzles help make mathematics learning more active and fun

description: Researchers have discovered how to design and place single-photon sources at the atomic scale inside ultrathin 2D materials, lighting the path for future quantum innovations.
title: Pinpointing the glow of a single atom to advance quantum emitter engineering

description: As the Christmas shopping period begins in earnest following Black Friday and Cyber Monday, new research led by the University of Birmingham and the University of Bristol sheds light on how consumers' environmental and social concerns fail to translate into ethical purchasing actions during online shopping.
title: Online shopping makes it harder to make ethical consumption choices, research says

description: With Australia's social media ban coming into force this week, a new survey from Monash University has found that almost 4 out of 5 Australian adults support the Australian government's social media ban for children under 16.
title: Four in five Australian adults support social media ban for kids

description: Businesses that operate in societies with strong social bonds are far less likely to manipulate their financial results, according to new research from the University of Portsmouth, suggesting that "having good friends" may be just as important as formal corporate rules in keeping companies honest.
title: Plenty of friends and strong social ties keep companies honest

description: Researchers at the Institute for Meteorology at Leipzig University have, for the first time, determined the climatic impact of contrails that form within natural cirrus clouds. Contrails account for the largest share of aviation's climate impact beyond carbon dioxide emissions.
title: 'Hidden' contrails in cirrus clouds contribute to climate warming, research finds

description: Two-dimensional (2D) semiconductors are thin materials (i.e., one-atom thick) with advantageous electronic properties. These materials have proved to be promising for the development of thinner, highly performing electronics, such as fitness trackers and portable devices.
title: Growth strategy enables coherent quantum transport in single-layer MoS₂ semiconductors

description: Nematodes discovered in the Great Salt Lake belong to at least one species that is new to science, and possibly two. A University of Utah research team has published a new paper characterizing the tiny roundworm. The team gave it a name that honors the Indigenous tribe whose ancestral lands include the lake.
title: Roundworms discovered in Great Salt Lake are new to science

description: Videogame avatars can offer safer alternatives for exploring and expressing gender identities for transgender and gender diverse people, according to a new research review.
title: Research reveals game avatars offer safe alternatives for exploring and expressing gender identities

description: Math students may not blink at calculating probabilities, measuring the area beneath curves or evaluating matrices, yet they often find themselves at sea when first confronted with writing proofs.
title: New AI-powered tool helps students find creative solutions to complex math proofs

description: Ganalay and guli are species of native grasses—used as a food source and ground into a flour—that used to thrive on the black alluvial soil plains of Moree, New South Wales, particularly after heavy rains or flooding.
title: Listening to Kamilaroi Women: Report findings highlight risk of losing art of cooking with native grasses

description: An atmospheric phenomenon occurring over much of California was unmistakable in satellite imagery in late autumn 2025. Fog stretching some 400 miles (640 kilometers) across the state's Central Valley appeared day after day for more than two weeks in late November and early December. Known as tule (TOO-lee) fog, named after a sedge that grows in the area's marshes, these low clouds tend to form in the valley in colder months when winds are light and soils are moist.
title: An unrelenting tule fog

description: The thunder of a rifle echoes across the Savannah. Antelope scatter as birds of all feathers take to the air. A dull thud signals that the marksman's shot was true. The horn from the felled rhino will command more money on the black market than the hunter could otherwise make in a year.
title: Researchers map Africa's snaring crisis, calling for sustainable solutions

description: France released on Friday a revamped roadmap to become carbon neutral by 2050, with an ambitious plan to phase out oil and gas.
title: France updates net-zero plan, with fossil fuel phaseout

description: In the wake of a wildfire, a vital micronutrient can become a toxic heavy metal—and could eventually make its way into groundwater.
title: Wildfires can turn harmless minerals in soils into contaminants, research shows

description: "Tis the season to extend social invitations to colleagues—a gesture that may seem simple, but research by an Indiana University Kelley School of Business Indianapolis professor and her colleagues shows these invitations can drive both positive and negative outcomes, shaping emotions and workplace behaviors.
title: Holiday party invites: A gift or a burden? Why that simple 'join us' can boost gratitude—or trigger stress

description: How do intermittent events like hurricanes impact natural selection? How do animals adapt to challenging weather? A University of Rhode Island professor has set out to track natural selection in the Anolis lizard over time to see how the species has weathered hurricanes in the southeastern United States.
title: Storm study shows adaptive selection in southeast lizards

description: When Buffalo, New York's devastating December 2022 blizzard claimed more than 30 lives, it exposed a hard reality: Even life-saving travel bans can lose their force over time, especially when residents face situations where compliance becomes difficult. The disruption stretched on for days, straining households' ability to stay supplied without venturing out.
title: Buffalo blizzard study shows travel bans lose effectiveness as storms persist

description: Researchers at University of Tsukuba have developed the Japanese version of the community-based rehabilitation indicators (CBR-Is), originally created by the World Health Organization to assess inclusive social participation among persons with disabilities. After a rigorous process of translation and cultural adaptation, the team confirmed that these indicators are suitable for use in the Japanese context.
title: Validating new Japanese indicators to assess inclusive social participation of persons with disabilities

description: Parasitic weeds extract water and nutrients from their host plants. But what makes these parasites so successful? A study led by Prof Susann Wicke from the Institute for Evolution and Biodiversity at the University of Münster and published in  Science Advances has shown that certain parasitic plants activate their feeding organs (haustoria) independently of the host plant. This strategy increases their ability to successfully infest the host.
title: 'Self-activation' is part of the success strategy of parasitic weeds

description: Aside from maybe high school biology classes, the first time many people heard of mRNA was during the pandemic because of the vital role MRNA technology played in COVID-19 vaccines.
title: It's being used to fight cancer, flu and the next pandemic, but what exactly is mRNA?

description: From saccharin in the 19th century to stevia and monk fruit in the 21st, researchers and the food industry have long sought a sweetener that delivers the taste of sugar without its drawbacks—excess calories, tooth decay, and heightened risk for obesity, insulin resistance, and diabetes.
title: A healthier sugar substitute: Engineered bacteria yield a sweet solution

description: Bacteria are among the most diverse and ancient forms of life on Earth. Yet, much of what is known about them comes from a small group of species, mostly studied for their roles in human health.
title: Swedish freshwater bacteria reveal lost genes and unexpected photosynthesis abilities

description: International humanitarian aid organizations rely on analyses from the Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) system, a global partnership that monitors and classifies the severity of food insecurity to help target assistance where and when it is most needed.
title: Global measures consistently underestimate food insecurity: 1 in 5 who suffer from hunger may go uncounted

description: Researchers have found a way to control protein levels inside different tissues of a whole, living animal for the first time. The method lets scientists dial protein levels up or down with great precision during the animal's entire life, a technological advance which can help them study the molecular underpinnings of aging and disease.
title: Plant hormone allows lifelong control of proteins in living animal for first time

description: A comprehensive analysis of 383 U.S. cities reveals a striking pattern: most have rings of isolation in suburban areas and segregated pockets near the urban core, that are shaped by race, wealth, and proximity to downtown, finds a new study by UCL researchers.
title: Hidden patterns of isolation and segregation found in all American cities

description: Elon Musk has signaled plans to soon seek a public stock listing of SpaceX, confirming a report that links the strategic shift to a near-term need for more capital.
title: Musk signals plan to launch IPO for SpaceX

description: Divers have discovered a long-submerged wall some 7,000 years old under the sea off western France, scientists said Thursday.
title: Ancient undersea wall dating to 5,800 BC discovered off French coast

description: An extraordinary botanical spectacle is drawing crowds in Rio de Janeiro: several talipot palm trees, planted more than six decades ago, are blooming for the first—and last—time in their lives.
title: 'In her prime': Rare blooming of palm trees in Rio

description: Indonesia's deadly flooding was an "extinction-level disturbance" for the world's rarest great ape, the tapanuli orangutan, causing catastrophic damage to its habitat and survival prospects, scientists warned on Friday.
title: Indonesia floods were 'extinction level' for rare orangutans

description: With science increasingly coming under attack, using humor as a way to get people interested in scientific research is more important than ever, the founder of the satirical Ig Nobel prizes said.
title: Laughing about science more important than ever: Ig Nobel founder

description: A 6.7 magnitude earthquake shook northeastern Japan and caused small tsunami waves but no apparent damage Friday, days after a stronger quake in the same region.
title: A 6.7 magnitude earthquake causes small tsunami waves off northeastern Japan

description: The man tracking chimpanzee movements in a rainforest is required to follow the primates wherever they go—except up in the trees.
title: Conservationists connect with chimps in a Ugandan rainforest as they seek a sense of communion

description: Mosasaurs, giant marine reptiles that existed more than 66 million years ago, lived not only in the sea but also in rivers. This is shown by new research based on analyses of a mosasaur tooth found in North Dakota and believed to belong to an animal that could reach a length of 11 meters.
title: Sea reptile's tooth shows that mosasaurs could live in freshwater
